titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, Kilolo Kijakazi FA1848
titlestmt.subtitle: Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, Kilolo Kijakazi

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 18:28:19 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, Kilolo Kijakazi

physdesc.extent: 93 boxes (81 letter document boxes, 11 legal document boxes, 1 oversize document box)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the subject files of Kilolo Kijakazi who served as a program officer within the Asset Building and Community Development division in the Economic Development department at the Ford Foundation. Kijakazi was key in determining the future of grantmaking in the Financial Assets unit starting in 2003. The collection spans from 1987-2014.
The collection includes grant working files, proposals, reports, conference materials, and correspondence.

The focus of Kijakazi's work was funding programs that provided pathways for low- and moderate-income families to build wealth. The Ford Foundation-funded initiatives that provided backing for this work included Saving for Education, Entrepreneurship and Downpayment (SEED), Building Economic Security Over a Lifetime (BESOL), and the American Dream Demonstration (ADD). These programs supported research and demonstrations of Child Development Accounts (CDAs), Child Savings Accounts (CSA), and Individual Development Accounts (IDA), efforts to preserve and improve Social Security benefits, educating policymakers in economic security issues at the state and federal level, provided grants to organizations involved in researching efforts to improve economic security, and supported grassroots efforts to improve asset building at the local and state level.

The collection also highlights Kijakazi's and the Ford Foundation's efforts to fund programs to close the racial wealth gap and utilize the expertise of, and build opportunities for, people of color in the research, policy, and practice of asset building work. The programs aimed to create universal, inclusive, and progressive saving and asset building policy in the U.S.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center received five accessions containing Kilolo Kijakazi's files from the Ford Foundation between 2020 and 2022: Accessions 2020:006, 2020:024, 2021:080, 2021:104, and 2022:029.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in one series with subseries organized by grantee, Ford-funded initiatives, and supporting documents.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation's Asset Building and Community Development division in the Economic Development department supported several large-scale initiatives involving grants to multiple grantees in the 2000s through the 2010s.

In 2002, the Ford Foundation provided $6.1 million to the American Dream Demonstration (ADD) project that tested the potential impact of individual development accounts (IDAs) on individual savings behaviors in 14 programs across the United States.

Beginning in 2003, the Foundation supported the Saving for Education, Entrepreneurship, and Downpayment Initiative (SEED). SEED was a 10-year national policy, practice, and research program to develop, test and promote matched savings accounts and financial education for children. One of the first goals of the program was to build the capacity of the Corporation for Economic Development (CFED) (renamed Prosperity Now in 2017) and the Center for Social Development (CSD) at Washington University in St. Louis. Other areas of SEED investment included 10 small-scale pilot projects administered by local foundations, a project focused on Head Start Centers in Michigan, a project that partnered with the State of Oklahoma (SEED for Oklahoma Kids) to provide savings accounts to children at birth, work by the New America Foundation to advocate for legislation, and funding for the Initiative on Financial Security (IFS) at the Aspen Institute. Ultimately, the Ford Foundation provided more than $30 million in support of the program.

In 2004, Ford funded a series of focus groups with different communities of color to determine the future directions of Financial Assets programming. Ford also supported annual convenings of experts of color in the field of asset building starting in 2004.

In 2009, Ford launched the Building Economic Security Over a Lifetime (BESOL) initiative to support research on saving and asset policy as well as local grassroots efforts, develop widespread support for state policy to create life cycle savings accounts, develop communications infrastructure linking national and state policy organizations, and fund research and advocacy to protect and improve Social Security. A focus of the program was to create a pipeline of scholars in the field of asset building from diverse backgrounds. The experts represented Black, Latin American, Native American, Native Hawaiian, Asian American, and Pacific Islander communities.
The Ford Foundation also provided grants to many other organizations involved in asset building work, including the following:
The Urban Institute's Academy for Public Policy Analysis and Research
National Academy of Social Insurance (NASI) for educating policymakers on the importance of Social Security to low-income families
Howard University's Center on Race and Wealth
Tuskegee University for recovery efforts following Hurricanes Katrina and Rita
Center for Social Development at Washington University
University of Michigan's Research and Training Program on Poverty and Public Policy
Earned Assets Resources Network (EARN)
Illinois Asset Building Group (IABG)
First Nations Development Institute
Center for Public Policy Priorities
Southern Regional Asset Building Coalition (SRABC)
Center for Community Change (CCC)
PolicyLink to build a communications system that would create an accountable public policy process
Duke University Research Network on Racial and Ethnic Inequality to measure the wealth gap by race, ethnicity, country of origin, and Native American tribal affiliation
Opportunity Agenda to develop a communications strategy and set of messages on the racial wealth gap.

Saving for Education, Entrepreneurship and Downpayment (SEED)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Saving for Education, Entrepreneurship, and Downpayment Initiative (SEED) was a 10-year, multi-million dollar national policy, practice and research program to develop, test and promote matched savings accounts and financial education for children. There were 10 small-scale pilot projects administered by local foundations, a project focused on Head Start Centers in Michigan, a project that partnered with the State of Oklahoma (SEED for Oklahoma Kids) to provide savings accounts to children at birth, work by the New America Foundation to advocate for legislation, and an Initiative on Financial Security at the Aspen Institute.

Funding partners included the Charles and Helen Schwab Foundation, Charles Stewart Mott Foundation, Citi Foundation, Edwin Gould Foundation for Children, Evelyn and Walter Haas Jr. Fund, Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation , The Ford Foundation, Jim Casey Youth Opportunity Initiative, Lumina Foundation for Education, MetLife Foundation, and the Richard and Rhoda Goldman Fund.
